Description: Circular wheel-made pottery lamp with a low body, a tall central tube that rises just above the level of the upper overhanging rim with a beaded inner edge. The tapering nozzle has a rounded tip and a large oval wick-hole. The underside nearly flat, with hole in the centre which runs up through a conical projection. Rear half of lamp is missing. Decorated with black paint on the nozzle and as bands around the rim, on the central tube and oil-chamber. Light yellow fabric.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Parallel from Athens (Howland 1958, Type 17A or 19 variant, see no.123). Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.10) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5899 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
